Patch Set 4:

(17 comments)

Lots of stuff still needs done to build this out;

In the meantime since we originally went down this road is whether or not there's a simpler "write" style API we can attach to the Response object that would have similar behavior, but would avoid a lot of the "upgrade" code associated with websockets, that isn't really worth the code cost here.

The non-functional strawman for dynamic responses is here.
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/39409

It would also help greatly, if you're interested in this core development, if you could help review the other core bmcweb patches that are currently in review.  I suspect some will have impact to this review, especially the SSL one.

Patch Set 4:

(7 comments)

> Patch Set 4:
> 
> (17 comments)
> 
> Lots of stuff still needs done to build this out;
> 
> In the meantime since we originally went down this road is whether or not there's a simpler "write" style API we can attach to the Response object that would have similar behavior, but would avoid a lot of the "upgrade" code associated with websockets, that isn't really worth the code cost here.
> 
> The non-functional strawman for dynamic responses is here.
> https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/39409
> 
I agree Ed, Once above review merges we can migrate the SSE stuff also along side with websocket/http connections. 
> It would also help greatly, if you're interested in this core development, if you could help review the other core bmcweb patches that are currently in review.  I suspect some will have impact to this review, especially the SSL one.
Sure Ed, I will spend time on reviewing other core bmcweb patches in review.

Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as 88ada3bc05ea247b6c8a24db49ebfdd268c17f4d
Nit  Duplicated title.
Done
Please word wrap properly, 50/72 is the standard here, which I would hope your editor can do for you automatically.
Done
We need to find a better way to handle upgrades here.  This is effectively adding yet another router into the connection layer, which is fine for a demo, but we can't do overall.

SSE connection stream need to be established upon GET of SSE specific URI. So the request in such case will be as if normal get request to any other routes. So i only differentiating factor here is only URI itself. 

Can you please advise here for a way to differentiate SSE request from other GET requests. Thanks in advance.

> SSE connection stream need to be established upon GET of SSE specific URI. So the request in such case will be as if normal get request to any other routes. So i only differentiating factor here is only URI itself. 
> 
> Can you please advise here for a way to differentiate SSE request from other GET requests. Thanks in advance.

Any answer would be gotten by looking at the SSE RFC specification.  I don't have any great ideas here, but it for sure needs solved.  Maybe look into how something like Flask solved it?  Most of our interfaces are derivations of theirs.

I did checked slask SSE implementation, W3C and widely available opensource examples, So there is no differentiating factor in request with normal GET request vs SSE uri. All places URI is used for routing the SSE request. So may be, we can maintain all SSE URI's in separate list and use it here. Do you agree?

That means that the information needs to go into the router, and be made available at runtime.  We've needed this for several other things, so it's probably time that we make the router available to the connection class in some way.

I'm not sure how to organize that, as I haven't really looked at it, but dynamic requests are going to need that too.

The list itself shouldn't go here.  Nothing in the HTTP classes should be openbmc specific, and they should be server-agnostic.
Hi Ed, This is quite old comment. Can you please check once and provide some lead here, to take it forward?

With the latest code change, the URL is no more hard coded.

sseRoutes are defined under sse_socket namespace, and called using Router
Done

This needs to remain private.  Handlers should not be overriding the completion handler.  If something else needs access to it, please declare it as a friend class, similar to how connection is done today.
I tried with friend class but facing many issues. I will resolve issues around making sse::Connection as friend to this instead.
Done
Nit, please just call this SseConnection instead of sse::Connection.
Done
Please remove this.  This should be coming out of req.session, which the user can do for themselves.
i think, extracting username from request and storing it will be handy. But agree currently its not used, we can add when need arises.
Done
On an sse connection there is no response, right?  I wouldn't expect this to be here.
If request has some invalid data(Example: $filter Query parameter), we need to response response and it used for same.
Response removed from sse connection class , and during error scenario, we use temporary asyncResp to send the response (complete handler)
Done
Remove.
Done
This is an sse connection.  Why would it ever "complete" in the normal sense?

Basically before starting the SSE event-stream, request need to be validated in terms of correctness( Example: Query parameters supplied as part of request is not correct,), need to respond and close the connection. So this call back is used to for the same.
Done
Please use boost::beast::lowest_layer
Done
No longer correct.  This has been changed since this patchset was started.
Done
Missing timeouts.
Will be addressed in the next patch that will be pushed.
Still not addressed.  Comment was made 2 years ago.
Addressed in the latest patch

Um..... not quite following this statement.  That doesn't mean we need to close the sse connection.  We probably also should be reading just to keep from buffer attacks, so we know to close the connection if the client disobeys the protocol.
Yes, We are reading the incoming data and then only we are closing the connection. I will try to update the comment.
Done

This would normally be

outBuffer.consume(bytesTransferred);
Done
Shouldn't eof close the connection too?
Done
SSE requests never "complete" they close.  This api seems incorrect.

basically if request packet has some invalid data(Example: $filter query params wrong), Before we start the SSE connection stream, We need to complete the request - By sending error response and close the connection. This API does the same completes the Request(by sending error response) and close the connection.
Done
string_view for both of these please
Done
50/72 please
Done
Continues to not be fixed.

Ed, I did checked the SSE documentation (W3C) and also googled, i don't see differentiating factor in request with Normal GET request vs SSE GET request? So other than URL itself, I don't see any request header(or some other) which can differentiate between Normal Vs SSE GET request. 

Websocket connections will have authorization header for identify and upgrade connection. But SSE, I can see only URL itself for identification. So used it. Did you come across any other way? Can you please suggest, if any?

> Ed, I did checked the SSE documentation (W3C) and also googled, i don't see differentiating factor in request with Normal GET request vs SSE GET request?

Which documents did you look at?  Please link them.

> So other than URL itself, I don't see any request header(or some other) which can differentiate between Normal Vs SSE GET request. 
> 
> Websocket connections will have authorization header for identify and upgrade connection. But SSE, I can see only URL itself for identification. So used it. Did you come across any other way? Can you please suggest, if any?

The problem isn't that you used the URL, it's that you hardcoded ONE SPECIFIC url outside of the router.  The whole point of the router abstraction is to find a handler for a url, and there's where I'd like the routes kept for abstraction purposes, otherwise, this causes a hard dependency on the http layer for all possible protocols (redfish, rest-dbus, ect) which doesn't scale.

Imagine if we had done the same for redfish, and in this file put:

if (req->url == "/redfish/v1" || 
req->url == "/redfish/v1/Systems" ||
.....


That would fall apart in a hurry, and it's the reason why the router exists.

With the latest code change, the URL is no more hard coded.

sseRoutes are defined under sse_socket namespace, and called using Router
Done
Hi Ed,  Can you please review and add your inputs/comments on this?

I went to review this more closely, and I see a "TODO discuss with community" in it, which tells me this should've been marked WIP.  Please mark it work in progress so that it doesn't take up maintainer time to review if it's not complete.  If there are specific sections that you'd like help with, like the above, please ping me on discord, or post specific comments on the lines where you'd like help.
Duplicate sign off.
Done
Done
Glad to see someone finally picking this up again.
Please rearrange your code such that forward declarations like this aren't required.
Why is this needed?
Done
This is pulling a redfish dependency into the router, which should have no knowledge of redfish.

This is not an appropriate check.  Registering a route like:

/mysse/<str> will fail this check.

You need to use something like find()
this-> not required here.  Please take a look at the declaration in http connection to make this template available.
Done
We generally don't set the server header.
server was set in server_sent_events.hpp file, so followed the same format
I don't understand your response.  this comment was made in server_sent_events.hpp.  What format are you following?
removed server header
Aren't these the defaults?
removed
Please make this a method rather than a lambda.  Please do this with all your lambdas.
Done
This should be async_wait?  You don't need to start a read, just wait for the socket to error.
std::size_t should be size_t
This capture is unsafe.
Done
Done
We're erroring out and closing here.  THere's no need to commit or consume.
Done
This return is redundant.
Done
const boost::system::error_code&
Done
size_t
Done
Please use the boost::beast::http::field enum rather than a string.
Done
For SSE, why is this required?  This is also duplicating some code.
Please make this a variable on the SSE class, so lifetime is easier.
Done

I believe this needs to be async_write_some?

Otherwise the connection will be completed.
Done
string_view doesn't need to be const.
Done
Please wrap this into a separate function and unit test it.
Done

Please make this a std::unique_ptr so that the memory can be reclaimed once  the connection is opened.

For these two, multi_buffer might be a better choice?
Followed the same implementation as present in connection.hpp
connection.hpp is different, because it reuses buffers in between keepalive requests.  This doesn't.
replaced flat_static_buffer with multi_buffer
None of these should be passing by shared_ptr.  the openHandler is not taking ownership of the connection.
openhandler calls createSubscription which needs shared_ptr, hence shared_ptr is passed
Why does createSubscription need shared_ptr?  It's not taking ownership of the Connnection.

Hi Ed Tanous/Gunnar Mills, 
I am seeing build failure, and errors are seen in files where my changes are not present. 
Build is successful in my local build server. 
I am not sure why these errors are being thrown, could you please help me in resolving this issue?
Done

Please help to review and test
https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/63887

With those changes, I think this patch can merge.

with the goal of getting this patchset moving, I've uploaded the next patchset in the series.  As written, I don't believe they have any effect on the output of bmcweb, because there are no handlers registered.  Lets work to get this stuff stabilized.

I am good with that. 
I support this feature.
